question: How does the movie John Wick compare to the movie Taken in terms of plot and premise?
contexts: ["Review: The best way I can describe John Wick is to picture Taken but instead of Liam Neeson it's Keanu Reeves and instead of his daughter it's his dog. That's essentially the plot of the movie. John Wick (Reeves) is out to seek revenge on the people who took something he loved from him. It's a beautifully simple premise for an action movie - when action movies get convoluted, they get bad i.e. A Good Day to Die Hard. John Wick gives the viewers what they want: Awesome action, stylish stunts,"]
ground_truth: The best way I can describe John Wick is to picture Taken but instead of Liam Neeson it's Keanu Reeves and instead of his daughter it's his dog. That's essentially the plot of the movie. John Wick (Reeves) is out to seek revenge on the people who took something he loved from him. It's a beautifully simple premise for an action movie.

The film improves on the previous installment and further establishes Keanu Reeves as the greatest martial arts action star of all time.

question: How has the 'John Wick' series managed to remain consistent in quality despite the trend of loathing movie sequels?

Incredibly, I think 'John Wick: Chapter 4' is the best the series has to offer. This movie was a wild ride."]
ground_truth: The 'John Wick' series has managed to remain consistent in quality by delivering well-received movies with the same IMDb rating of 7.4/10 for all three films. Despite the general trend of loathing movie sequels, the series has maintained a high level of consistency and quality, with 'John Wick: Chapter 4' being considered the best installment yet.

question: How did the second John Wick film expand on the narrative and world-building of the first film?
contexts: ['Review: It is 5 years since the first John Wick film - one that took me by surprise by how silly it was as a narrative, but yet how well it delivered action sequences. The second film was only 2 years ago, and it raised the stakes and went from a man seeking revenge on another group of people, into one where the world was filled with assassins, popping up from everywhere all the time. I remember ending that film feeling like it had gone too far but that the third would probably do more of that.']
ground_truth: The second John Wick film expanded on the narrative and world-building of the first film by raising the stakes and transitioning from a simple revenge story to a world filled with assassins. It introduced a broader scope of characters and situations, creating a more complex and interconnected world for John Wick to navigate.

question: What role does the Continental hotel play in the movie John Wick: Chapter 2?
contexts: ["Review: After resolving his issues with the Russian mafia, John Wick (Keanu Reeves) returns home. But soon the mobster Santino D'Antonio (Riccardo Scamarcio) visits him to show Wick's marker and tells that he needs to help. John Wicks refuses since he is retired and Santino blows-up his house. John Wick meets the owner of the Continental hotel in New York City, Winston (Ian McShane), and he tells that Wick cannot violate the Mafia rules and shall honor the marker. Santino asks John Wick to kill"]
ground_truth: The Continental hotel in New York City, owned by Winston, serves as a safe haven for assassins and a neutral territory where no 'business' can be conducted. It enforces the rules of the underworld, including the prohibition of 'conducting business' on its premises. John Wick seeks refuge and assistance from Winston after his house is blown up by Santino D'Antonio.

question: What sets JOHN WICK apart from other action films with its emotional story and detailed world?
contexts: ["Review: JOHN WICK is a rare example of Hollywood getting things spot-on when it comes to creating the near-perfect action film. JOHN WICK is a relentless, pulse-pounding thriller that has plenty of similarity to the Liam Neeson classic TAKEN, albeit with a more simplistic (and also more emotionally intense) plot line. This is the kind of lean, pared-down film-making that's all about intensity and momentum. It sits well with classic international fare like POINT BLANK, SLEEPLESS NIGHT, MEA", 'Review: John Wick is something special. It takes as much time setting up elaborate action sequences as it does the world with which it all takes place in. And what a world it is. It reminds me of Millers Crossing and it is cooler than any other recent attempt at noir. We are shown a criminal underworld where, if you are connected, many powerful people know who you are and show you respect. John Wick was connected but he got out. He is the rare killer who has found peace, and he is grateful for']

question: What triggers John Wick's revenge mission in the movie with Tarantino-style dialogue and 70s action star vibe?
contexts: ['a brutal home invasion that leaves his beloved dog murdered by thugs from his past, John Wick vows revenge on the ones who have taken what he loves most. Like I said, on paper, this seems like a direct-to-DVD slopfest starring John Cena but as a film with Keanu Reeves as the lead, it marks the very welcomed return for Reeves to the genre. John Wick is insanely fun, violently brutal and an overall romp especially for those disappointed by The Expendables 3. John Wick is propelled by', "the very welcomed return for Reeves to the genre. John Wick is insanely fun, violently brutal and an overall romp especially for those disappointed by The Expendables 3. John Wick is propelled by Tarantino-esque dialog mixed with the swagger of action stars from the 70s. Reeves literally emulates cool in this film and does it with such confidence, that we don't even doubt the character...even when he kills countless bad guys with extreme force in some utterly ridiculous and implausible"]
ground_truth: John Wick's revenge mission is triggered by a brutal home invasion that results in the murder of his beloved dog by thugs from his past. This event leads him to vow revenge on those who have taken what he loves most.

question: How does humor improve the enjoyment of John Wick 3?
contexts: [": 13\nReview: Following on from two deliriously entertaining, visually gorgeous and blissfully simplistic thrillers, John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum keeps up the franchise's unique appeal in stunning fashion. Complete with electrifying action, beautiful cinematography, a pulsating score and a great sense of humour, the film is pretty much as purely joyful as action thrillers get, and proves two hours of brilliant entertainment.", ": 24\nReview: John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum is quite literally about consequences, dealing with the fallout of John's actions at the end of the previous film and sending him on an even bigger odyssey of violence that continues to explore this world of assassination and deliver beautifully clean action sequences."]
ground_truth: Humor in John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum adds to the enjoyment by providing moments of levity amidst the intense action sequences. It helps balance the tension and violence with comedic relief, making the overall experience more engaging and entertaining for the audience.

question: What was John Wick's previous job in the movie?
contexts: ["Review: Wow what a great surprise this was. I was told by a friend this was good but it's been awhile since I liked a Keanu movie so I was hesitant to try it. Retired hit-man John Wick (Keanu Reeves) loses his wife to cancer. After her funeral he receives a puppy she left him. A few days later some thugs, led by the son of a Russian gangster John used to work for, break into John's house. They beat him up, take the keys to his beloved car, and kill the puppy. They did this not knowing who he", "Review: If you've seen the first John Wick movie, you know that Keanu Reeves is John Wick, a retired assassin who comes out of retirement when someone kills his dog. In this one, which begins a week later, matters are still reverberating, and some one has stolen his car, which calls for a lot of carnage. That settled, John is called on to pay off an old debt by helping Ian McShane take over the Assassin's Guild by flying around to Italy, Canada and Manhattan and killing what seems like hundreds"]
ground_truth: John Wick's previous job in the movie was a retired hit-man.

One scene in particular that will have your blood"]
ground_truth: One scene in particular that will have your blood pumping is a showdown between thugs and Wick in a nightclub. This action sequence remains the best in the film and will have you grasping your theater seat because of the sheer intensity of it.

question: Why does John Wick go to Rome for a contract despite the bounty on his head?
contexts: [': 17\nReview: Picking up where the first movie left off, John Wick still wants his car back. Also, he now discovers that there is a bounty on his head. Rejoining his former profession, he heads to Rome to complete an assassination assignment.']
ground_truth: John Wick goes to Rome for a contract despite the bounty on his head because he reenters his former profession and takes on an assassination assignment in order to complete it.
